segment.source: Users expect an app to remain responsive while it does computation, regardless of the type of machine.
segment.target: Users expect an app to remain responsive while it does computation, regardless of the type of machine.

segment.source: This means different things for different apps.
segment.target: This means different things for different apps.

segment.source: For some, this translates to providing more realistic physics, loading data from disk or the web faster, quickly presenting complex scenes and navigating between pages, finding directions in a snap, or rapidly processing data.
segment.target: For some, this translates to providing more realistic physics, loading data from disk or the web faster, quickly presenting complex scenes and navigating between pages, finding directions in a snap, or rapidly processing data.

segment.source: Regardless of the type of computation, users want their app to act on their input and eliminate instances where it appears unresponsive while it "thinks".
segment.target: Regardless of the type of computation, users want their app to act on their input and eliminate instances where it appears unresponsive while it "thinks".

segment.source: Your app is event-driven, which means that your code performs work in response to an event and then it sits idle until the next.
segment.target: Your app is event-driven, which means that your code performs work in response to an event and then it sits idle until the next.

segment.source: Platform code for UI (layout, input, raising events, etc.) and your app’s code for UI all are executed on the same UI thread.
segment.target: Platform code for UI (layout, input, raising events, etc.) and your app’s code for UI all are executed on the same UI thread.

segment.source: Only one instruction can execute on that thread at a time so if your app code takes too long to process an event then the framework can’t run layout or raise new events representing user interaction.
segment.target: Only one instruction can execute on that thread at a time so if your app code takes too long to process an event then the framework can’t run layout or raise new events representing user interaction.

segment.source: The responsiveness of your app is related to the availability of the UI thread to process work.
segment.target: The responsiveness of your app is related to the availability of the UI thread to process work.

segment.source: You need to use the UI thread to make almost all changes to the UI thread, including creating UI types and accessing their members.
segment.target: You need to use the UI thread to make almost all changes to the UI thread, including creating UI types and accessing their members.

segment.source: You can't update the UI from a background thread but you can post a message to it with CoreDispatcher.RunAsync to cause code to be run there.
segment.target: You can't update the UI from a background thread but you can post a message to it with CoreDispatcher.RunAsync to cause code to be run there.

segment.source: Note The one exception is that there's a separate render thread that can apply UI changes that won't affect how input is handled or the basic layout.
segment.target: Note The one exception is that there's a separate render thread that can apply UI changes that won't affect how input is handled or the basic layout.

segment.source: For example many animations and transitions that don’t affect layout can run on this render thread.
segment.target: For example many animations and transitions that don’t affect layout can run on this render thread.

segment.source: Delay element instantiation
segment.target: Delay element instantiation

segment.source: Some of the slowest stages in an app can include startup, and switching views.
segment.target: Some of the slowest stages in an app can include startup, and switching views.

segment.source: Don't do more work than necessary to bring up the UI that the user sees initially.
segment.target: Don't do more work than necessary to bring up the UI that the user sees initially.

segment.source: For example, don't create the UI for progressively-disclosed UI and the contents of popups.
segment.target: For example, don't create the UI for progressively-disclosed UI and the contents of popups.

segment.source: Use x:DeferLoadStrategy to delay-instantiate elements.
segment.target: Use x:DeferLoadStrategy to delay-instantiate elements.

segment.source: Programmatically insert elements into the tree on-demand.
segment.target: Programmatically insert elements into the tree on-demand.

segment.source: CoreDispatcher.RunIdleAsync queues work for the UI thread to process when it's not busy.
segment.target: CoreDispatcher.RunIdleAsync queues work for the UI thread to process when it's not busy.

segment.source: Use asynchronous APIs
segment.target: Use asynchronous APIs

segment.source: To help keep your app responsive, the platform provides asynchronous versions of many of its APIs.
segment.target: To help keep your app responsive, the platform provides asynchronous versions of many of its APIs.

segment.source: An asynchronous API ensures that your active execution thread never blocks for a significant amount of time.
segment.target: An asynchronous API ensures that your active execution thread never blocks for a significant amount of time.

segment.source: When you call an API from the UI thread, use the asynchronous version if it's available.
segment.target: When you call an API from the UI thread, use the asynchronous version if it's available.

segment.source: For more info about programming with async patterns, see Asynchronous programming or Call asynchronous APIs in C# or Visual Basic.
segment.target: For more info about programming with async patterns, see Asynchronous programming or Call asynchronous APIs in C# or Visual Basic.

segment.source: Offload work to background threads
segment.target: Offload work to background threads

segment.source: Write event handlers to return quickly.
segment.target: Write event handlers to return quickly.

segment.source: In cases where a non-trivial amount of work needs to be performed, schedule it on a background thread and return.
segment.target: In cases where a non-trivial amount of work needs to be performed, schedule it on a background thread and return.

segment.source: You can schedule work asynchronously by using the await operator in C#, the Await operator in Visual Basic, or delegates in C++.
segment.target: You can schedule work asynchronously by using the await operator in C#, the Await operator in Visual Basic, or delegates in C++.

segment.source: But this doesn't guarantee that the work you schedule will run on a background thread.
segment.target: But this doesn't guarantee that the work you schedule will run on a background thread.

segment.source: Many of the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) APIs schedule work in the background thread for you, but if you call your app code by using only await or a delegate, you run that delegate or method on the UI thread.
segment.target: Many of the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) APIs schedule work in the background thread for you, but if you call your app code by using only await or a delegate, you run that delegate or method on the UI thread.

segment.source: You have to explicitly say when you want to run your app code on a background thread.
segment.target: You have to explicitly say when you want to run your app code on a background thread.

segment.source: In C#C# and Visual Basic you can accomplish this by passing code to Task.Run.
segment.target: In C#C# and Visual Basic you can accomplish this by passing code to Task.Run.

segment.source: Remember that UI elements may only be accessed from the UI thread.
segment.target: Remember that UI elements may only be accessed from the UI thread.

segment.source: Use the UI thread to access UI elements before launching the background work and/or use CoreDispatcher.RunAsync or CoreDispatcher.RunIdleAsync on the background thread.
segment.target: Use the UI thread to access UI elements before launching the background work and/or use CoreDispatcher.RunAsync or CoreDispatcher.RunIdleAsync on the background thread.

segment.source: An example of work that can be performed on a background thread is the calculating of computer AI in a game.
segment.target: An example of work that can be performed on a background thread is the calculating of computer AI in a game.

segment.source: The code that calculates the computer's next move can take a lot of time to execute.
segment.target: The code that calculates the computer's next move can take a lot of time to execute.

segment.source: In this example, the handler returns at the await in order to keep the UI thread responsive.
segment.target: In this example, the handler returns at the await in order to keep the UI thread responsive.

segment.source: But execution picks up in that handler again after (which executes on a background thread) completes.
segment.target: But execution picks up in that handler again after (which executes on a background thread) completes.

segment.source: The remaining code in the handler updates the UI with the results.
segment.target: The remaining code in the handler updates the UI with the results.

segment.source: Note There's also a ThreadPool and ThreadPoolTimer API for the UWP, which can be used for similar scenarios.
segment.target: Note There's also a ThreadPool and ThreadPoolTimer API for the UWP, which can be used for similar scenarios.

segment.source: For more info, see Threading and async programming.
segment.target: For more info, see Threading and async programming.
